with Nvhich mankind has battled

When party politics become unusually corrupt, resulting in the
election of incompetent officials,
everybody but the favored few,
suffers. So it is with student politics. Supposedly intelligent and
"broad-minded" students in our

if we are anxious to keep student organizations efficient strong

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 6, 1924

IMPORTANT AFFAIRS
At Thursday's Assembly undoubtedly the most important business of the whole year is to be transacted, primarily, the election of
the President of the Student Council and membes of the Athletic
Association, and secondarily, the choice of the most popular man in
the Senior Class. In a recent issue of The News-Letter, we discussed
the former two and in this connection we are pleased to publish an
exchange editorial expressing the views of a condition, analogous to
the one at Hopkins, existing at another college.
This time seems an appropriate one to give a word of explanation, especially to the Freshmen, of what is meant by the "most popular man." Briefly, by the most popular man in the Senior Class is
not meant the best personal friend of the individual voter, but, the
one man among the Seniors most generally liked by every ,one on
;
the campus.
May we repeat a thought from a previous editorial—"Vote, but
above all things, vote intelligently."

MALICIOUS FRATERNITY POLITICS
Many of the campus societies and clubs have already held their
annual elections for new members and officers, and as the end of the
school year approaches, the four classes, as well as various other campus organizations, contemplate similar action. With the annual question of elections comes an aggravation of the perennial question of
fraternity politics.
It is a self-evident fact that to attempt to eliminate fraternity
politics from Penn State elections or from elections at any college
where there are fraternities, would be useless. Not only would the
attempt be useless; it is unnecessary. Fraternity politics, like many
another necessary evil, are harmless until carried to excess, but when
uncontrolled they may, and frequently do, wreak havoc.
In every election, whether it is for membership in a society or
whether it is for organization officers, mediocre men win honors
along with more gifted or hard-wOrking aspirants, because of the influence of fraternities in campus ballotings.
But when the season arrives at which the various groups and
classes choose officers, then fraternity politics frequently become malicious. Perhaps some student remembers that a fraternity brother
whom he had hoped would be successful in a previous election suffered defeat because of the dissenting vote of another student. If
the candidate was unfitted for the place, it is obvious that the unfavorable ballot was entirely justifiable. But the aforementioned
student realizes only that his ambitions for his fraternity's glory have
been thwarted, and he awaits an opportunity'to avenge his fancied
wrong. In doing this he ignores all concern as to the qualities of the
candidate who is the victim of his vengeance. His sole thought is to
discomfit the student who caused the defeat of his fraternity brother.
If he succeeds, the organization in which he is voting loses, and the
college loses. Especially is this true if students who are unfitted for
the honors bestowed and the responsibilities entailed "come through"
in the elections.
Our campus problems are generally built along the lines of those
of the outside world. The problem of fraternity politics strongly re-

UNDERGRADUATES
GET PLAYSHOP
OFFICES
Two undergraduates were elected to office at the annual election
of the Homewood Playshop last
William E.
Friday evening.
Trout, '25, was elected treasurei
and R. Earl Parks, '25, was reelected Art Director.
The other officers are:
J. E. Uhler, A. M., '24, president.
Albert G. Langeluttig, Jr., '22,
secretary.
G. W. Small, Ph.D., '23, Litertor.
G. H. Pouder, Dramatic DirecMiss Irma Williams, Music Director.
Rex Sims, Business !Manager.
The officers form the executive
council which governs the Playshop until the next election of officers.
The issue at the election was
the degree of connection with the
university. The group elected,
supported by the faculty, stand
for close connection with the university, especially the undergrads.
The opposition, which had a complete ticket in the field, stood upon
a platform of virtual independence
from the university. The university group was elected by an overwhelming majority.
The meeting was opened by a
message by President Uhler in
which he emphasized the increase
in the undergraduate membership
in the Playshop and the attempts
of the Playshop to encourage undergraduate co-operation.
He
cited the loan of the building to
the Sigma Upsilon Literary Fraternity and a number of projected
activities in which the Playshop
will co-operate with the undergraduates.
After the reading of the message the organization moved
quickly to the election. The presence of over 25 undergraduates,
who voted solidly for the university group, was one of the deciding factors.
CANE CLUB ELECTS AT
DINNER
After a dinner at the Hopkins
Club the Cane Club elected the following officers: President, Philip
Howard; vice-president, John
Baker; treasurer, Otho J. Keller
III; Master of ceremonies, John
Webster.
It was decided that a hack be
secured for the use of members
during June Week and a stag
party was arranged to celebrate
the end of exams.

T. R. Marsh, former president
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., is
chairman of the Y. M. C. A. and
Y. W. C. A. State Officers Training Conference, which will be hold
at Blue Ridge College, New Windsor, 1VId. The dates for the conference are May 2, 3 and 4.
The conference, which is an annual one, was also conducted by
Mr. Marsh last year. He is also
chairman of the program committee of this year's meeting. The
..CCI1C of the convention last year
was -Western Maryland College,
having been held the year before
at the Central Y. M. C. A., at Baltimore.
The admission of i- he Y. W. C.
A. marks an innovation in the Officers Training Conferences which
until this year have been restricted to the Y. M. C. A. This year's
conference, too, will be singular
in the fact that it will be conducted entirely by students.
Purposes of the conference are
as follows: To discuss the campus situation; to discuss methods
of organization and co-operation;
to discuss methods of unifying the
work of Christian associations on
the campus; to discuss methods of
co-operation between the student
Y. M. C. A. and Y. W. C. A., and
to assist the new officers in the
solving of some of their problems.
Each college which will be represented at the conference will
send as delegates the newly elected officers of the Y. M. C. A. and
the Y. W.C. A. or other members
of the cabinet. The following colleges will have representation:
Hopkins, Goucher, University of
Maryland, Hood, Washington,
Western Maryland, Blue Ridge,
St. John's and the Maryland State
Normal School.
Leaders of the discussion group
will be chosen from the various
delegations. Hopkins leaders of
such groups are: Reno S. Harp,
whose group will discuss "Forces
at Work on the Campus ;" and
Karl E. Miller, whose group will
discuss "Finance." Julian Price, of
the Hopkins Medical School, will
address the conference on "Frienciship."

to Thursday afternoon's program

Competition for the excellence
in shooting in the R. 0. T. C.
unit will be held from May 12 to
May 6 inclusive. The contest
positively closes May 16. Any
member of the R. 0. T. C. is eligible. Medals will be awarded by
the Baltimore News for the first
and second highest men.

A graduate scholarship in electrical engineering is offered members of. the graduating class in engineering schools by the School of
Mines, Engineering and Chemistry of Columbia University. The
scholarship, which is to be awarded through the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, will cover
all tuition fees and will be awarded for a three-year span providing
the student maintains a satisfactory standing in his work.
The course at Columbia is three
years in length and is on a graduate basis. Although three years
of preparatory work in college or
scientific school is usually considered as sufficient, a college graduate with a Bachelor of Science
degree in engineering can generally qualify to better advantage.
No special examinations are required in this test, the candidate
being admitted on the basis of his
previous collegiate record. Columbia authorities state that "the purpose of this advanced course is to
produce as high type of engineer,
trained in the humanities as well
as in the fundamentals of his. profession."
Candidates should apply immediately to the secretary of the A.
I. E. E., Mr. F. L. Hutchinson,
33 West 39th St., New York City.
FINAL TEST FOR BEST
DRILLED PRIVATE
Final competition for the best
drilled private in the R. 0. T. C.
unit will be held sometime this
week. Four men have been selected from each of the four companies who will participate in the
individual competition before reviewing officers.
C. R. Howard, winner of the
cup given for the best drilled private last year, is not eligible this
year, since the cup changes hands
annually and cannot be contested
for by previously successful holders. Lieutenant Sherwood has
given out the names of the four
men from each company who have
been chosen to compete. The 16
men, and the companies which
they represent, are as follows:
Company A—Beckwith, Donald
M.; Berman, Henry I.; Frantz,
Douglass S.; Gibson, Thomas L.
Company B—Brawner,Jean C.
Langeluttig, Harry V.; Maguire,
Jack B.; McNeal, Thomas F.
Company C—Cleveland, Malcolm; Suchting, William H.; Torres, Eugenio; Ward, Charles L.,
Jr.
Company D—Corby, Roy A.
Cushing, Charles F.; Kleff, Arnold J.; Marley, George E.

CAUSE OF CAVE-IN A MYSTERY
Although work on the new
Chemistry Building has again advanced to the point where it was
at its setback, no one has offered
a satisfactory explanation of the
cavein of lecture room 101. The
few facts known are these: On
April 10 the workmen poured half
of the concrete flooring of the lecture hall; when they returned next
morning to complete the work
they found that all the concrete
which had already been poured
had fallen in during the night.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 6, 1924

IMPORTANT AFFAIRS
At Thursday's Assembly undoubtedly the most important business of the whole year is to be transacted, primarily, the election of
the President of the Student Council and membes of the Athletic
Association, and secondarily, the choice of the most popular man in
the Senior Class. In a recent issue of The News-Letter, we discussed
the former two and in this connection we are pleased to publish an
exchange editorial expressing the views of a condition, analogous to
the one at Hopkins, existing at another college.
This time seems an appropriate one to give a word of explanation, especially to the Freshmen, of what is meant by the "most popular man." Briefly, by the most popular man in the Senior Class is
not meant the best personal friend of the individual voter, but, the
one man among the Seniors most generally liked by every ,one on
;
the campus.
May we repeat a thought from a previous editorial—"Vote, but
above all things, vote intelligently."

MALICIOUS FRATERNITY POLITICS
Many of the campus societies and clubs have already held their
annual elections for new members and officers, and as the end of the
school year approaches, the four classes, as well as various other campus organizations, contemplate similar action. With the annual question of elections comes an aggravation of the perennial question of
fraternity politics.
It is a self-evident fact that to attempt to eliminate fraternity
politics from Penn State elections or from elections at any college
where there are fraternities, would be useless. Not only would the
attempt be useless; it is unnecessary. Fraternity politics, like many
another necessary evil, are harmless until carried to excess, but when
uncontrolled they may, and frequently do, wreak havoc.
In every election, whether it is for membership in a society or
whether it is for organization officers, mediocre men win honors
along with more gifted or hard-wOrking aspirants, because of the influence of fraternities in campus ballotings.
But when the season arrives at which the various groups and
classes choose officers, then fraternity politics frequently become malicious. Perhaps some student remembers that a fraternity brother
whom he had hoped would be successful in a previous election suffered defeat because of the dissenting vote of another student. If
the candidate was unfitted for the place, it is obvious that the unfavorable ballot was entirely justifiable. But the aforementioned
student realizes only that his ambitions for his fraternity's glory have
been thwarted, and he awaits an opportunity'to avenge his fancied
wrong. In doing this he ignores all concern as to the qualities of the
candidate who is the victim of his vengeance. His sole thought is to
discomfit the student who caused the defeat of his fraternity brother.
If he succeeds, the organization in which he is voting loses, and the
college loses. Especially is this true if students who are unfitted for
the honors bestowed and the responsibilities entailed "come through"
in the elections.
Our campus problems are generally built along the lines of those
of the outside world. The problem of fraternity politics strongly re-

UNDERGRADUATES
GET PLAYSHOP
OFFICES
Two undergraduates were elected to office at the annual election
of the Homewood Playshop last
William E.
Friday evening.
Trout, '25, was elected treasurei
and R. Earl Parks, '25, was reelected Art Director.
The other officers are:
J. E. Uhler, A. M., '24, president.
Albert G. Langeluttig, Jr., '22,
secretary.
G. W. Small, Ph.D., '23, Litertor.
G. H. Pouder, Dramatic DirecMiss Irma Williams, Music Director.
Rex Sims, Business !Manager.
The officers form the executive
council which governs the Playshop until the next election of officers.
The issue at the election was
the degree of connection with the
university. The group elected,
supported by the faculty, stand
for close connection with the university, especially the undergrads.
The opposition, which had a complete ticket in the field, stood upon
a platform of virtual independence
from the university. The university group was elected by an overwhelming majority.
The meeting was opened by a
message by President Uhler in
which he emphasized the increase
in the undergraduate membership
in the Playshop and the attempts
of the Playshop to encourage undergraduate co-operation.
He
cited the loan of the building to
the Sigma Upsilon Literary Fraternity and a number of projected
activities in which the Playshop
will co-operate with the undergraduates.
After the reading of the message the organization moved
quickly to the election. The presence of over 25 undergraduates,
who voted solidly for the university group, was one of the deciding factors.
CANE CLUB ELECTS AT
DINNER
After a dinner at the Hopkins
Club the Cane Club elected the following officers: President, Philip
Howard; vice-president, John
Baker; treasurer, Otho J. Keller
III; Master of ceremonies, John
Webster.
It was decided that a hack be
secured for the use of members
during June Week and a stag
party was arranged to celebrate
the end of exams.

T. R. Marsh, former president
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., is
chairman of the Y. M. C. A. and
Y. W. C. A. State Officers Training Conference, which will be hold
at Blue Ridge College, New Windsor, 1VId. The dates for the conference are May 2, 3 and 4.
The conference, which is an annual one, was also conducted by
Mr. Marsh last year. He is also
chairman of the program committee of this year's meeting. The
..CCI1C of the convention last year
was -Western Maryland College,
having been held the year before
at the Central Y. M. C. A., at Baltimore.
The admission of i- he Y. W. C.
A. marks an innovation in the Officers Training Conferences which
until this year have been restricted to the Y. M. C. A. This year's
conference, too, will be singular
in the fact that it will be conducted entirely by students.
Purposes of the conference are
as follows: To discuss the campus situation; to discuss methods
of organization and co-operation;
to discuss methods of unifying the
work of Christian associations on
the campus; to discuss methods of
co-operation between the student
Y. M. C. A. and Y. W. C. A., and
to assist the new officers in the
solving of some of their problems.
Each college which will be represented at the conference will
send as delegates the newly elected officers of the Y. M. C. A. and
the Y. W.C. A. or other members
of the cabinet. The following colleges will have representation:
Hopkins, Goucher, University of
Maryland, Hood, Washington,
Western Maryland, Blue Ridge,
St. John's and the Maryland State
Normal School.
Leaders of the discussion group
will be chosen from the various
delegations. Hopkins leaders of
such groups are: Reno S. Harp,
whose group will discuss "Forces
at Work on the Campus ;" and
Karl E. Miller, whose group will
discuss "Finance." Julian Price, of
the Hopkins Medical School, will
address the conference on "Frienciship."

Competition for the excellence
in shooting in the R. 0. T. C.
unit will be held from May 12 to
May 6 inclusive. The contest
positively closes May 16. Any
member of the R. 0. T. C. is eligible. Medals will be awarded by
the Baltimore News for the first
and second highest men.

A graduate scholarship in electrical engineering is offered members of. the graduating class in engineering schools by the School of
Mines, Engineering and Chemistry of Columbia University. The
scholarship, which is to be awarded through the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, will cover
all tuition fees and will be awarded for a three-year span providing
the student maintains a satisfactory standing in his work.
The course at Columbia is three
years in length and is on a graduate basis. Although three years
of preparatory work in college or
scientific school is usually considered as sufficient, a college graduate with a Bachelor of Science
degree in engineering can generally qualify to better advantage.
No special examinations are required in this test, the candidate
being admitted on the basis of his
previous collegiate record. Columbia authorities state that "the purpose of this advanced course is to
produce as high type of engineer,
trained in the humanities as well
as in the fundamentals of his. profession."
Candidates should apply immediately to the secretary of the A.
I. E. E., Mr. F. L. Hutchinson,
33 West 39th St., New York City.
FINAL TEST FOR BEST
DRILLED PRIVATE
Final competition for the best
drilled private in the R. 0. T. C.
unit will be held sometime this
week. Four men have been selected from each of the four companies who will participate in the
individual competition before reviewing officers.
C. R. Howard, winner of the
cup given for the best drilled private last year, is not eligible this
year, since the cup changes hands
annually and cannot be contested
for by previously successful holders. Lieutenant Sherwood has
given out the names of the four
men from each company who have
been chosen to compete. The 16
men, and the companies which
they represent, are as follows:
Company A—Beckwith, Donald
M.; Berman, Henry I.; Frantz,
Douglass S.; Gibson, Thomas L.
Company B—Brawner,Jean C.
Langeluttig, Harry V.; Maguire,
Jack B.; McNeal, Thomas F.
Company C—Cleveland, Malcolm; Suchting, William H.; Torres, Eugenio; Ward, Charles L.,
Jr.
Company D—Corby, Roy A.
Cushing, Charles F.; Kleff, Arnold J.; Marley, George E.

CAUSE OF CAVE-IN A MYSTERY
Although work on the new
Chemistry Building has again advanced to the point where it was
at its setback, no one has offered
a satisfactory explanation of the
cavein of lecture room 101. The
few facts known are these: On
April 10 the workmen poured half
of the concrete flooring of the lecture hall; when they returned next
morning to complete the work
they found that all the concrete
which had already been poured
had fallen in during the night.
